div.head: Probable Results of the Present War
div.excerpt: "...a second Canada as it were, shall stretch itself from one end of their border line to the other, what security will remain for the perpetuity of slavery?"
div.summary: Summarizes why war will evidently be worse for the South, even if it is victorious. It is argued that Southern debt will be crippling and that slavery will be even less secure as the abolition party will have full sway in Northern affairs.

div.head: Personal
div.summary: Valley Spirit asks that its subscribers pay what they owe.

div.head: Resigned
div.summary: Reports the resignation of Capt. Reilly from the McClure Rifles.

div.head: A Warning to the Democracy
div.excerpt: "The Times Newspaper, of this place, hissed on by its abolition master, makes a most unprovoked and malignant attack on the Spirit in its issue this week."
div.summary: The Spirit criticizes the Times as an abolition paper, alleging that free-soil and abolition have led to the dissolution of the Union.

div.head: Read It
div.excerpt: "Secession was the very worst remedy to which the South could have resorted to redress her wrongs. Had she remained in the Union...she could have commanded the sympathy and support of the Northern Democracy."
div.summary: Calls attention to the page 1 article from the Lutheran Observer and endorses its views wholeheartedly.

div.head: How to Judge Them
div.summary: Spirit responds to charges of Confederate sympathy and friendship with South Carolina.

div.head: Important from the Seat of War
div.summary: Reports that the Union army marched to Centreville, Virginia on the morning of July 18th. There is an unconfirmed rumor that an engagement with the rebels occurred at Centreville.
